author: gvcgael
body:
# Steps to reproduce

Run `pwsh` on Debian Buster (Debian 10) and starts to type commands.

# Expected behavior

pwsh is usable, user can type commands and read outputs.

# Actual behavior

There seems to be a problem with the buffers. Typing commands and running them does not work after the first one. Like if the buffers get unsynchronized with the inputs/outputs of the terminal. 

# Environment data

I reproduce this problem with a snap install of pwsh and with the tar.zf archive. 

```
PS /opt> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.2.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.2.3
OS                             Linux 4.19.0-6-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.19.67-2 (2019-08-28)
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body: @gvcgael Can you remove PSReadline module ( Remove-Module PSReadline ) and test again?

comments.author: gvcgael
comments.body:
Remove-Module PSReadline does not change the behaviour of powershell.

Ok, it seems that the problems comes from my setup.

I connect from Git bash via SSH to my Debian buster VM. In this case, I get these buffers problem.

Using directly the console, powershell behaviour is ok.

Any idea what could be the cause ?

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
I guess the scenario was never tested.
At first we should check that C# API works right in the scenario. You could create simple C# application and check that Console.ReadKey() and Readline() methods work well.

comments.author: gvcgael
comments.body:
Ok, it seems that I was wrong. It comes from the fact that I run git bash on Visual Studio Code.

Outside of studio code, it behaves properly. So it seems to come from the terminal integrated in VSC.

comments.author: iSazonov
comments.body:
> So it seems to come from the terminal integrated in VSC.

@TylerLeonhardt In which repository should we track this?

comments.author: TylerLeonhardt
gvcgael
comments.body:
Hello,

I'm using VSCode Git bash integrated terminal, from which I connect to the VM where I run pwsh.

comments.author: TylerLeonhardt
comments.body:
Ok in that case, the correct repo would be: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode since you are not using the "PowerShell Integrated Console", this issue is with VSCode itself - not the PowerShell extension and since it works outside of VSCode, it's not a PowerShell bug either. Can you open this over there? Make sure you're clear in saying that it works outside of vscode and that you're using gitbash as your shell in vscode. Also tag me in it so I can jump in if need be.
